metadata.titleEn: Data set of temporal and spatial distribution of metal element concentrations in snow and ice at Zhongshan Station Dome A Section, Antarctica (1990-2017)
metadata.description: Based on the 33rd Antarctic Scientific Expedition in China, the data set of temporal and spatial distribution of metal element concentrations in snow and ice obtained on the section from Zhongshan Station to Dome A in East Antarctica mainly includes: 1. A shallow ice core obtained 202 km away from Zhongshan Station. The ice core covers the period from 1990 to 2017 with a resolution of years, including metal element iron, hydrogen and oxygen isotopes and other data. 2. Collect a sample every 10km along the Zhongshan Station Dome A section in East Antarctica. The metal elements include rare earth elements, barium and other elements. The data can be used to study the pollution and contribution of natural sources and human activities to Antarctic snow and ice.
metadata.instructions: The data includes two Excel tables, which list the concentration of snow and ice elements and the dating results of ice cores.

authorList.unitEn: Cold and Arid Regions Environmental and Engineering Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences

background: Iron bioavailability is taken as a limit factor for primary productivity in approximately 40% of the world’s oceans. A significant external iron source to the open ocean is the atmospheric input and particularly the atmospheric deposition of mineral dust from continental regions. Volcanic events, continental shelf and iceberg are also important Fe sources. Therefore, it is still not clear which one is much more important for primary productivity in the Southern Ocean, although the Fe hypothesis has been demonstrated on three High Nutrient Low Chlorophyll (HNLC) regions of the surface ocean where today vanishingly-low dissolved Fe concentrations limit phytoplankton growth. In particular, the magnitude of the bioavailable Fe controls how much the atmospheric CO2 changes during glacial-interglacial cycles, which is very uncertainly. Many dissolved Fe data in seawater from the international GEOTRACES program have been published to elucidate the distributions of Fe in seawater at the global scale. This greatly increases our knowledge of the marine geochemistry of Fe element, however, it is still limited ice core Fe data for paleoclimate study. Recent work also suggests that Fe fertilization likely accounts for 5 to 30 ppmv of the change in the CO2 concentrations observed over glacial-interglacial transitions in Antarctica ice cores. More importantly, with global warming, the ice melting of Greenland ice sheet may release much more bioavailable Fe to the ocean.
research objective: In this study, a shallow ice core (12.5 m) was drilled from the Lambert Glacial Basin, East Antarctica during the 33rd Chinese National Antarctic Research Expedition. DFe and TDFe concentrations were measured and their fluxes were estimated during 1990–2017. The results emphasized that the aeolian mineral dust and volcanic events are thought to be primary Fe sources, and the anthropogenic biomass burning may affect Fe releasing during 1990–2017.
methods: In this study, a shallow ice core (12.5 m, called LGB) was drilled at the Lambert Glacial Basin, East Antarctica. The major ion and metal elements were measured at 5e6 cm resolution in this shallow core, which covered the period 1990e2017.
dataset: The data utilized in this manuscript is found in 4TU.ResearchData.
findings: Our results emphasized that much more dissolved Fe (DFe) from the Cerro Hudson volcanic event (August 1991) was transported to the East Antarctic ice sheet, in comparison with the Pinatubo volcanic event (June 1991). The aeolian dust may be the primary DFe source during 1990–2017. In particular, the DFe variations may be affected by the biomass burning emissions in two periods (1990–1998 and 2014–2017). While total dissolved Fe (TDFe) variations were controlled by the climatic conditions since 2000 because of the temperature (d18O) decreasing at East Antarctica. These Fe data will be useful to assess the modern bioavailable Fe release for the Antarctica ice sheet.

Verification.Question: Is there a specific focus on the concentration of iron and rare earth elements in the collected ice core samples?
Are volcanic events considered in the analysis of metal element sources in the studied ice cores?

Disjunctive.Question: Are metal element concentrations in ice cores typically measured using high-resolution techniques (5-6 cm), annual resolution methods, or other techniques on the East Antarctic ice cores?
Are the variations in total dissolved iron (TDFe) in East Antarctic ice more influenced by volcanic events, biomass burning, or climatic conditions since 2000?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary sources of iron in the Southern Ocean, and how might they vary over time?
Concept Completion.Answer: atmospheric input, volcanic events, continental shelf, icebergs

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the shallow ice core drilling site located for collecting metal element data in East Antarctica?
When was the data collection period covered by the shallow ice core from East Antarctica?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how a dataset can be utilized to understand the sources of dissolved iron to the East Antarctic ice sheet?
Example.Answer: The dataset includes DFe and TDFe concentrations and their fluxes estimated from the Lambert Glacial Basin ice core, emphasizing the contribution of aeolian mineral dust and volcanic events as primary Fe sources during 1990–2017.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the snow ice and ice core metal element concentration data collected from the Zhongshan Station-Dome A transect in Antarctica?
Feature Specification.Answer: spatial and temporal distribution, 1990 to 2017, shallow ice core, 202 kilometers from Zhongshan Station, annual resolution, metal elements like iron, hydrogen-oxygen isotopes, samples every 10 kilometers, rare earth elements, barium

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features are measured in the ice core that was drilled from the Lambert Glacial Basin, East Antarctica?
Feature Specification.Answer: 12.5 meters deep, major ion and metal elements, resolution of 5 to 6 cm, period from 1990 to 2017, dissolved iron (DFe) concentrations, total dissolved iron (TDFe) concentrations, flux estimates

Quantification.Question: How many samples were collected along the East Antarctic Zhongshan Station-Dome A section for the metal element concentration dataset?
What was the length of the ice core drilled for the metal element concentration data collected during the Chinese National Antarctic Research Expedition?
Over how many years does the ice core data for metal elements cover, and what is its temporal resolution?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'spatial distribution data' in the context of snow ice metal element concentration studies?
Definition.Answer: In the context of snow ice metal element concentration studies, 'spatial distribution data' refers to the collection of data samples at various locations, such as every 10 kilometers along a transect, to understand how metal elements like rare earth elements and barium are distributed across a specific region, such as the East Antarctic Zhongshan Station to Dome A transect.

Comparison.Question: How does the metal element measurement resolution in ice cores compare to the sampling interval along the East Antarctica transect in terms of capturing temporal variations?
Comparison.Answer: The metal elements in the ice cores were measured at a resolution of 5-6 cm, covering the period from 1990 to 2017, which provides high-resolution temporal data. In contrast, samples along the East Antarctica transect were collected every 10 kilometers, which gives spatial distribution data but may not capture fine temporal variations as effectively as the ice core measurements.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the sources of iron considered in the ice core analysis compared to those in the open ocean studies?
Comparison.Answer: Both the ice core analysis and open ocean studies consider aeolian mineral dust and volcanic events as primary sources of iron. However, the ice core analysis specifically highlights the impact of anthropogenic biomass burning on iron release, which is not a primary focus in open ocean studies where continental shelves and icebergs are also considered significant sources of iron.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of measuring dissolved iron in ice cores differ from those encountered in seawater, particularly in terms of paleoclimate studies?
Comparison.Answer: Measuring dissolved iron in ice cores for paleoclimate studies is limited by the historical data available, which can be sparse compared to the more comprehensive datasets from programs like GEOTRACES for seawater. Additionally, ice core studies face the challenge of isolating anthropogenic influences like biomass burning, which do not significantly affect seawater iron measurements. The focus in ice cores is more on historical climatic conditions, while seawater studies aim to elucidate current global distributions of iron.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn about the impact of climatic conditions on total dissolved Fe variations from the observed data between 2000 and 2017 in East Antarctica?
Interpretation.Answer: The climatic conditions, particularly the decrease in temperature (as indicated by d18O data), appear to control the variations in total dissolved Fe since 2000. This suggests that climatic shifts can alter the geochemical processes affecting iron concentrations in ice cores, highlighting the sensitivity of Fe deposition to environmental changes.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the data on biomass burning emissions from 1990–1998 and 2014–2017 contribute to understanding human impact on Fe release in Antarctica?
Interpretation.Answer: The data indicating that biomass burning emissions may have affected dissolved Fe variations during these periods suggest a link between human activities and Fe release in Antarctica. This highlights the potential influence of anthropogenic factors on the biogeochemical cycles in polar environments, offering insights into how human-induced emissions can alter natural processes in remote regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the selection of sampling locations along the snow and ice transect from Zhongshan Station to Dome A for collecting metal element concentration data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Sampling locations along the snow and ice transect from Zhongshan Station to Dome A are selected based on the need to capture spatial distribution of metal elements, with samples collected every 10 kilometers to provide comprehensive coverage. This method ensures a detailed understanding of the metal elements, including rare earth elements and barium, in this region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might the concentration of dissolved iron in East Antarctic ice cores vary due to different environmental events over time?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The concentration of dissolved iron in East Antarctic ice cores can vary due to environmental events such as aeolian mineral dust deposition and volcanic events. For instance, the Cerro Hudson volcanic event in August 1991 contributed significantly to increased dissolved iron levels in comparison to other events like the Pinatubo volcanic eruption in June 1991. Additionally, biomass burning emissions during specific periods (1990-1998 and 2014-2017) may influence the variations in dissolved iron levels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes might lead to the observed changes in total dissolved iron variations in East Antarctica since 2000?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Changes in total dissolved iron variations in East Antarctica since 2000 are primarily caused by climatic conditions, particularly the decrease in temperature as indicated by d18O measurements. This climatic change impacts the deposition and concentration of dissolved iron in the region's ice cores.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using ice core data from the Lambert Glacial Basin to infer the sources of iron deposition in the East Antarctic region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using ice core data from the Lambert Glacial Basin can help identify primary iron sources such as aeolian mineral dust and volcanic events, and assess the impact of anthropogenic biomass burning on iron release during 1990–2017.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the outcomes of measuring metal elements at a high resolution in shallow ice cores for understanding past climate conditions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: High-resolution measurements of metal elements in shallow ice cores can reveal variations in dissolved iron that are influenced by volcanic events, aeolian dust, and climatic conditions, providing insights into past climate conditions and bioavailable iron release.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of integrating aeolian dust data from East Antarctica on the understanding of bioavailable iron's role in climate change?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating aeolian dust data can highlight its role as a primary source of dissolved iron, affecting bioavailability and influencing climate change through variations in atmospheric CO2 during glacial-interglacial transitions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended research objectives behind collecting metal element concentration data from snow and ice cores along the Zhongshan Station-Dome A transect in East Antarctica?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The research objectives include understanding the spatiotemporal distribution of metal elements, such as iron, and isotopes from 1990 to 2017, to study natural sources and human activities' contributions to Antarctic snow and ice pollution.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of measuring and analyzing total dissolved iron and other elements in shallow ice cores from East Antarctica?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to estimate the fluxes of dissolved iron and understand their primary sources, like aeolian mineral dust and volcanic events, as well as the impact of anthropogenic activities such as biomass burning on Fe release.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers differentiate between natural and anthropogenic sources of metal elements in Antarctic ice cores when analyzing the data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The research emphasizes differentiating sources by analyzing variations in dissolved Fe (DFe) from events like volcanic eruptions, aeolian dust, and anthropogenic biomass burning, using historical and climatic context to identify potential periods and sources.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for collecting high-resolution metal element data from ice cores in Antarctic regions?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of high-resolution metal element data from ice cores in Antarctic regions requires drilling shallow ice cores, such as a 12.5 m ice core, and measuring major ion and metal elements at a precise resolution of 5-6 cm, covering specific time periods like 1990-2017.

Enablement.Question: How does the spatial sampling strategy along a transect from Zhongshan Station to Dome A enable comprehensive analysis of snow and ice metal element distribution?
Enablement.Answer: A spatial sampling strategy that involves collecting samples every 10 kilometers along the Zhongshan Station to Dome A transect enables comprehensive analysis by providing data on the spatial distribution of metal elements, including rare earth elements and barium, which can be used to study the effects of natural sources and human activities on Antarctic snow and ice pollution.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how could future datasets be expanded or refined to enhance our understanding of the contribution of natural sources versus anthropogenic activities to Antarctic snow and ice pollution?
Judgmental.Answer: Future datasets could be expanded by incorporating longer ice core records, including additional sampling sites to capture regional variability, and integrating other environmental proxies such as isotopic compositions. Refinements could also include improved analytical methods to differentiate between natural and anthropogenic sources of pollutants more accurately. Enhanced datasets would better support the assessment of the relative contributions of natural events and human activities to Antarctic snow and ice pollution.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the metal elements are accurately measured in the snow and ice samples collected from East Antarctica.
Assertion.Answer: The major ion and metal elements were measured at 5 to 6 cm resolution in a shallow ice core that covered the period from 1990 to 2017.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the role of anthropogenic activities in influencing metal concentrations in the Antarctic ice cores.
Assertion.Answer: The research suggests that anthropogenic biomass burning may affect the release of iron during the period from 1990 to 2017, influencing metal concentrations in the ice cores.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the spatial distribution of metal elements in snow and ice from the Zhongshan-Dome A transect is determined.
Assertion.Answer: Samples were collected every 10 kilometers along the Zhongshan-Dome A transect, which included measurements of metal elements such as rare earth elements and barium, to determine their spatial distribution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used for measuring metal elements in ice cores and discuss their resolution and time coverage.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methods used for measuring metal elements in ice cores involved drilling a shallow ice core (12.5 m) at the Lambert Glacial Basin, East Antarctica. Major ions and metal elements were measured at a resolution of 5 to 6 cm, and the time coverage was from 1990 to 2017.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the potential for expanding datasets by incorporating additional samples along the East Antarctic transect, focusing on rare earth elements and barium.
Request/Directive.Answer: The dataset mentioned includes samples collected every 10 kilometers along the East Antarctic transect from Zhongshan Station to Dome A, focusing on metal elements including rare earth elements and barium. This approach could potentially be expanded by collecting more samples along the transect to enhance the dataset's comprehensiveness.
